item.title: Book Review: Linchpin; and, How to Create a Self-Study Course to Master Anything
item.description: [caption id="attachment_1872" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Vola Vale on Flickr"][/caption] “The best contribution one can make to humanity is to improve oneself.” - Anon I’ve always felt that learning is one of the best ways to improve oneself (I guess you could get philosophical and point out that self-improvement is essentially learning in one form or another). Reading books is one of the best ways to learn, which is why I include a lot of book reviews here.

item.title: Make Mistakes to Learn
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1313" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Jeffrey Montes on Flickr"][/caption]

The man who makes no mistakes does not usually make anything. - William Connor Magee

One of the productivity newsletters I subscribe to, Psychotactics, recently sent out an article on the best strategies to learn and retain knowledge. The author explained that almost every attempt we make to acquire knowledge is done in such a way as to make it very unlikely we will actually be able to hold on to that knowledge. The reason is simply because we are afraid to test our knowledge and make mistakes and mistakes are the key to knowledge retention.

item.title: Teacher Appreciation
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1247" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Abhijit Tembhekar on Flickr"][/caption]

Wax on, wax off. - Mr. Miyagi, the Karate Kid (1984)

Warriors are always seeking to grow and learn new things, so it makes sense that we'd have a lot of teachers in our life. As the year comes to a close and I contemplate my card list, I'm realizing that most of the people on it are my teachers and mentors. In the past two years, I've acquired an unusually large number of teachers, of exceptionally good quality, and I realize that all the growth and knowledge I've acquired is largely thanks to their efforts.
